hustfxj:

Hi, Turn worker garbage collection and heapdump on by default in jstorm.Different types of workers may diff about gc's JVM parameter, which support rolling back.User can custom path/name and jvm parameter.Jstorm output heapdump file per 10 minutes. These parameters support custom. If Jstorm found the worker will be dead, due to insufficient memory or time-out, it can output heapdump file.The gc file's default name is %TOPOLOGYID%worker%ID%-%time%.

zhuoliu:

Thanks John Fang for sharing the configuration in jstorm. In Storm defaults, the gc.log and heapdump (for OOM error) files will be stored under worker-uuid/artifacts, which soft-links to storm-local/workers-artifacts/topoID/workerPort/. And users can view and download these files together with other logs in logviewer UI.

commit 0c2021e6331cb5324a2803aff9783b539a05f63c
Author: Kishor Patil
Date: 2015-11-02T18:51:58Z

Adding dynamic profiling for worker

It looks good to me.  I am a little bit concerned that there is no way to turn this off, partially or all the way.  So for windows where there is currently no support for this we will end up trying to run a shell script that will fail, and if someone does not have/want commercial java support from Oracle, i.e. using open JDK, or IBM JDK, etc.  They have to make code modifications, not just config modifications to not show users buttons that will not work.

Could we put in something that could let users turn off part or all of this feature?  At a minimum in the UI, but it would be good if nimbus could also let users know that this particular feature is not currently configured on, and if the worker could see the config and know to add in `-XX:+UnlockCommercialFeatures -XX:+FlightRecorder` on the command line.

Other then that I am +1.

githubbot:

Could we put in something that could let users turn off part or all of this feature? At a minimum in the UI, but it would be good if nimbus could also let users know that this particular feature is not currently configured on, and if the worker could see the config and know to add in ```-XX:+UnlockCommercialFeatures -XX:+FlightRecorder``` on the command line.

STORM-1149. Support pluggable data sources in CREATE TABLE.

This PR implements the support of external data sources in CREATE TABLE. StormSQL can parse the CREATE TABLE statement, creates the data sources objects and processes the data based on the compiled SQL statement.

Github user HeartSaVioR commented on the pull request:

Except minor header issue then it's great! +1.

@revans2 Thank you for the feedback. Following changes should help make this feature completely optional and pluggable.   
- Added `worker.profiler.enabled` to shutdown use of profilers - 
  - If disabled, UI simply removes the section **Profiling and Debugging** section. 
  - If disabled, the supervisor would not add "worker.profiler.childopts" to worker JVM options - hence avoiding issues with jvm that does not provide commercial JProfiler. 
- Added `worker.profiler.command` to specify which script to use at supervisor level so that it can be customized for different profiler scheme.

githubbot:

Github user kishorvpatil commented on the pull request:

https://github.com/apache/storm/pull/842#issuecomment-153257989

@revans2 Thank you for the feedback. Following changes should help make this feature completely optional and pluggable.

  • Added `worker.profiler.enabled` to shutdown use of profilers -
  • If disabled, UI simply removes the section *Profiling and Debugging* section.
  • If disabled, the supervisor would not add "worker.profiler.childopts" to worker JVM options - hence avoiding issues with jvm that does not provide commercial JProfiler.
  • Added `worker.profiler.command` to specify which script to use at supervisor level so that it can be customized for different profiler scheme.
Currently, this feature lacks support for windows and command-line interface.

revans2:

Yes if you could create a reproducible use case that would be great. The code in question is the task receiver, which processes tuples sent to a bolt. It expects to see a list of tuples in a batch, not individual tuples. If an individual tuple showed up it would cause an exception like this. There are a few places in the code where tuples are injected directly into a receiver queue, the tick tuple, and the metrics tick are the ones that come to mind, but all of them explicitly insert a list for the single tuple they put in. There is also the possibility that something in the batching code is not handling one use case properly and not putting in a list, but without a reproducible use case it is really hard to tell.
+1 it looks like a great addition.

+1

revans2:

Harsha,

The problem is that it is not actually a dependency of storm-core. It is a dependency for an HttpServletFilter pulled over from Hadoop that can be added in after the fact. When people try to look at storm dependencies they see that hadoop-auth is not used and they remove it. Perhaps what we really need to do is to have a separate external package that pulls in the ui filter and all the dependencies it needs. Then we can have simple instructions on how to configure the filter using either the 

${storm.home}/extlib-daemon

directory or preferably the 

STORM_EXT_CLASSPATH_DAEMON

environment variable and 

storm_env.ini

. This way it would not add an unnecessary dependency on the classpath for anyone, and it is properly packaged + documented as an official part of storm.
+1 NB

JIRA name is STORM-162?

Based on the associated JIRA and from looking at the commits this pull request contains, this needs to go through the IP Clearance process [1].

From what I can tell, it's a significant amount of code that was developed internally at Yahoo, possibly by more than one contributor. The first commit introduces a lot of the code, and on the surface it's unclear where it came from.

The process is easy, we would just need a grant from Yahoo, and a list of contributors. Then it's just a matter of filling out the paperwork and waiting 72 hrs. for review.

I'll volunteer to do all the IP Clearance work/coordination.

[1] http://incubator.apache.org/ip-clearance/index.html

GitHub user zhuoliu opened a pull request:

https://github.com/apache/storm/pull/848

STORM-902 Simple Log Search

This feature is aimed for greatly improving the debugging of Storm.
Simple Log Search supports following important functionalities:

1. String search:
In UI, user can search certain string, e.g., "Exception", in for a certain worker log.
This search can happen for both normal text log or rolled zip log files. In addition, user can specify the number of matches to show in the search result.
2. Deep search:
User can search for a string for a certain topology, which means the UI will try to search on all the supervisor nodes in a distributed way to find the matched string in all logs for this topology.
Then the matched results can be shown on the UI with url links, directing user to the certain logs on each supervisor node. This powerful feature is very helpful for users to find certain problematic supervisor nodes running this topology.

Also, the topology history REST API is added to give hints for the previously launched topology IDs for a certain user. And the html files, images files, js file, test resource files and unit tests are added for log search and its tests.

You can merge this pull request into a Git repository by running:

$ git pull https://github.com/zhuoliu/storm 902

Alternatively you can review and apply these changes as the patch at:

https://github.com/apache/storm/pull/848.patch

To close this pull request, make a commit to your master/trunk branch
with (at least) the following in the commit message:

This closes #848

dossett@gmail.com:

Hi, this feature was included in STORM-969.

@ptgoetz I know you want to be careful about what gets merged in, and if you insist we will go through the IP clearance process, but if we can avoid it I really would prefer to do so.  We have not had any issues in the past with large commits, like when we contributed the security code to storm which followed essentially the same process as this code. On my end it is probably going to take longer than the 72 hour waiting period to track down the right people to get signatures and they will all ask me why we have to do this when my team has blanket approval to contribute to storm.

Like I said if you insist on getting IP clearance we will do it, but all it is just going to do is add more pain for me which I really would like to avoid if I can.

Sorry at Yahoo we have a separate single sign on, which I wish would die but that is a different discussion, so I don't completely understand how the SPNEGO code is packaged. If hadoop-auth provides all of the functionality that we need for the HttpServletFilter then yes, we should have it as a part of storm-core, and put a big comment in the pom that explains why it is here along with a big 'DO NOT TOUCH'. I would prefer to have it be shaded or only installed on the daemon classpath to avoid conflicts with different versions of Hadoop that a user might want instead, but that is just me.

@dossett none of us have permission for those files, in fact they are probably gone by now.  Travis only saves what was output to the log.  You could put in something in the ./dev-tools/travis that will spit out the contents of rat.txt files if the build fails because of rat.
